dialogues.text: Double Absolut martini.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Would you like to hear the specials?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Not if you want to keep your spleen. The Waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: This is a real beehive of, uh, activity, Halberstam.  This place is hot, very hot.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Listen, the mud soup and the charcoal arugula are outrage here.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you're late.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm a child of divorce. Give me a break  (Studying the menu; he's in a surprisingly good mood)  Hmmm, I see they've omitted the pork loin with lime jello

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: We should've gone to Dorsia. I could've gotten us a table

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Nobody goes there anymore. There is a long disgruntled silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Is that Ivana Trump over there? (Laughs) Jeez  Patrick I mean Marcus, what are you thinking? Why would I be at Texarkana? Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: So, wasn't Rothschild originally handling the  Fisher account? How did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: I could tell you that, Halberstam, but then I'd have  to kill you. He guffaws. Bateman laughs politely.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Paul Owen is very drunk. BATEMAN cold sober.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I like to dissect girls. Did you know I'm utterly insane? Owen continues laughing and motions to the waiter for ano drink.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Great tan, Marcus. Really impressive. Where do you tan? BATEMAN Salon.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: I've got a tanning bed at home. You should look into it. Bateman nods, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: And Cecelia, how is she? Where is she tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Cecelia is, well...you know (Cecelia. I think  she's having dinner with...Evelyn Williams.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Evelyn. Great ass. Goes out with that loser Patrick  Bateman. What a dork.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Another Martini, Paul? Owen nods drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The end of the meal. Owen is squeezing a lime onto the  table, missing his beer, incredibly drunk. The check is l down.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Talking to Owen like a child)  Paul, give me your Amex card. Good boy. Bateman slaps the card down, looks at the check.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Two-hundred-and-fifty. Very reasonable. Let's leave  a big tip, shall we? My place hr a nightcap?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: No, man. I'm gonna bail.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Come on, you dumb son of a bitch.  (Helping him into his jacket)  I've got a preview of the Barneys catalogue and a  bottle of Absolut waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room floor has been meticulously covered with  newspaper. Owen is slumped drunkenly in a white Eames chair, a glass in his hand. Bateman is looking through his CDs.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: You like Huey Lewis and the News?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: They're okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Their early work was a little too New Wave for my  taste. But then Sports came out in 1983, I think they rea came into their own, commercially and artistically. Bateman walks to his bathroom, taking a large ax out of t shower. He takes two Valium.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Said partly from the bathroom)  The whole album has a clear, crisp sound and a new sheen consummate professionalism that gives the songs a big boo Bateman comes back out and leans the ax against the wall. He walks to the foyer and puts on a raincoat, watching Ow from behind ail the time.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: He's been compared to ELvis Costello but I think  Huey has a more bitter, cynical sense of humor. Owen is absent-mindedly leafing through the Barneys  catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Hey, Halberstam?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Owen?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Why are there copies of the Style section all over  the place? Do you have a dog? A chow or something?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No, Owen.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (Confused)  Is that a raincoat?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. Bateman moves to the CD player. He takes a CD out of its  case and slides it in the machine.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: In 1987 Huey released this, Fore!, their most  accomplished album. I think I heir undisputed masterpiece "HiP To Be Square," a song so catchy that most people pro don't listen to the lyrics. But they should because it's just about the pleasures of conformity and the importance trends. It's al~ a personal statement about the band itse Bateman puts on "Hip To Be Square." BATEMAN crosses the room and picks up the ax. We follow BATEMAN from behind as he walks up to Owen, the ax raised over his head.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Paul? As Owen turns around, FROM OWEN'S POV we see Bateman swin the ax toward his face. Blood sprays onto the white raincoat. FROM BEHIND OWEN, we see BATEMAN as he yanks the ax out. Owen drops to the floor. His body falls out of the frame. We stay on his legs twitching mechanically. Blood pulses onto the newspaper-covered floor.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Raising the ax and screaming)  Try getting a reservation at Dorsia now, you fucking  stupid bastard! LOW ANGLE ON BATEMAN as he beats Owen with the back of th ax. OFFSCREEN, the sound of the ax hitting Owen.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Panting)  Fucking bastard... Bateman takes his raincoat off, still panting. He folds t coat carefully in half, bloody side in, and drapes it nea over the back of a chair. He sits back on the white sofa and surveys the scene. He  checks his Rolex and lights a cigar. OFFSCREEN, Paul Owen's last faint sighs are heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATEMAN drags a large, blood-soaked sleeping bag through past the bored doorman, who looks up from the Post for a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATEMAN is trying to hail a cab. Owen's body is at his  feet. Luis Carruthers and a Japanese girl walk up to him.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Patrick? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No, Luis. It's not me. You're mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: This is Gwendolyn Ichiban. This is my very good  friend Patrick Bateman. Where are you going? We're going Nell's. Gwendolyn's father's buying it.  (Looking down at the body)  Where did you get your overnight bag?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Commes des Garcon. A cab stops. BATEMAN opens the door and manages to get  Owen's body into the backseat. Bateman gets into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Call me please, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Jesus lives, Luis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bare room, lit by one light bulb. The walls are blank  except for a Les Miserables poster. There is one ratty ch Bateman pours lime over Paul Owen's body, which is lying a bathtub. He plays Huey Lewis, smokes a cigar, watches t body dissolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman is letting himself into the apartment. It is very similar to Bateman's, but even more minimalist. The walls are white-pigmented concrete with a large minimalist pain on the wall. One wall is covered in a trendy, large-scale scientific drawing above a long, black leather couch.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Where to send the bastard? Dallas? Pans? He throws some clothes into a suitcase, randomly grabbing toiletries and shoving them in.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Singapore? London. I'll send the asshole to London. He puts some music on to help muffle his voice, then lean over the answering machine. He does a passable imitation of Owen's speech.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Paul. I've been called away to London  for a few days. Meredith, I'll call you when I get back.  Hasta la vista, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman is sitting at his desk, with the latest copy of  Sports Illustrated in front of him and his Walkman playin Kenny G. We hear the MUSIC until Jean enters and he takes the Walkman off.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Faintly irritable)  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Condescendingly)  Ye-es, Je-an?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Patrick, a Mr. Donald KIMBALL is here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Detective Donald KIMBALL? Silence. Bateman stares out the window, then down at the  drawing of a headless woman he's been doodling on the bac cover of Sports Illustrated.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm at lunch.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (whispering)  Patrick, I think he knows you're here.  It's only ten-thirty.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Send him in, I guess. As she exits, he picks up the cordl phone and pretends to talk to someone at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Now, John, you've got to wear clothes in proportion  to your physique. There are definite do's and don'ts, goo buddy, of wearing a bold-striped shirt. A hold-striped sh calls for solid-colored or discreetly patterned suits and The door to the office opens and he waves in DETECTIVE DO KIMBALL. KIMBALL is surprisingly young - about Bateman's and good-looking, dressed in a crumpled linen Armani suit the type Bateman and his friends might wear. Kimball sits down and crosses his legs with a  self-assurance that makes Bateman so nervous he forgets t carry on with his fake conversation. Kimball looks up at  him curiously, noticing the silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Realizing that Kimball is staring at him)  Right. And yes...always tip the stylist fifteen percent. Bateman shrugs at the detective, rolling his eyes in  exasperation.  KIMBALL nods understandingly.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Listen, John, I've got to go. T Boone Pickens just  walked in... (He laughs inanely)  Just joking... (Pause)  No don't tip the owner of the salon. Okay, John,  right, got it.  (He hangs up the phone and pushes the antenna in)  Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. I should've made an appointment.  (Gesturing toward the phone)  Was that anything important?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh that? Just mulling over business problems.  Examining opportunities...Exchanging rumors... Spreading gossip. They laugh politely.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (Holding out his hand)  Hi. I'm Donald KIMBALL

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Shaking firmly)  Hi. Pat Bateman. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to barge in on you like this. but I was suppose to talk to Luis Carruthers and he wasn't in and...well,  you're here, so...I know how busy you guys can get. KIMBALL stares at the three open copies of Sports  Illustrated and the Sony Walkman lying on Bateman's desk. Bateman sees the look and sweeps the magazines  into the top drawer along with the Walkman, which is  still running.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Forcing himself to sound friendly and relaxed)  So, what's the topic of discussion?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I've been hired by Meredith Powell to investigate  the disappearance of Paul Owen.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: You're not with the FBI or anything, are you?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Nothing like that. I'm just a private investigator.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Ah, I see...Yes. Paul's disappearance...Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: So it's nothing that official. I just have some  basic questions. About Paul Owen. About yourself-

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No. I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Perrier? San Pellegrino?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No, I'm okay. KIMBALL takes out a small black notepad and the same gold Cross pen that Bateman and his friends all use. Bateman b Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Can you bring Mr...

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Kimball a bottle of San Pelle-

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Oh no, I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: It's no problem Bateman watches intently as KIMBALL writes something down in his notebook, then crosses something out. Jean enters  and places the bottle of San Pellegrino and a Steuben etc glass on the table, shooting a concerned glance at Batema He glares at her. KIMBALL smiles and nods at Jean as she

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, what's the topic of discussion?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: The disappearance of Paul Owen.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh right. Well, I haven't heard anything about the  disappearance or anything... (Trying to laugh)  Not on "Page Six" at least.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I think his family wants this kept quiet.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Understandable.  (Staring at the untouched bottle of San Pellegrino)  Lime?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No, really. I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: You sure? I can always get you a lime. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Just some preliminary questions that I need for my own  files, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Twenty-six. I'll be twenty-seven in October.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (Scribbling in his notebook)  Where did you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Harvard. The Harvard Business School.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Your address?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Fifty-five West Eighty-First Street. The American Gardens Building.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (Looking up, impressed)  Nice. Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Flattered)  Thanks. A pause as KIMBALL studies his notebook. Bateman closes h eyes, as if in pain.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Pardon me, but are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Who do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: You seem...nervous. Bateman reaches into his desk drawer and brings out a  bottle of aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Nuprin? KIMBALL Uh...no, thanks. Kimball takes out a pack of Marlboro's and lays it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Bad habit.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I know. I'm sorry. A pause, as Bateman stares at the cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Would you rather I not smoke?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No, I guess it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No problem.  (Buzzing Jean)

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Bring us an ashtray for Mr. KIMBALL, please. She whisks in with a crystal ashtray as they sit in silen

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: What can you tell me about Paul Owen?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Well... He coughs, shakes two Nuprin into his hand and swallows  them dry.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: How well did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I'm...at a loss. He was part of that whole...Yale thing,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Yale thing? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah...Yale thing.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: What do you mean...Yale thing? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, I think for one that he was probably a closet  homosexual. Who did a lot of cocaine...that Yale thing. A silence during which the sound of the air conditioner  becomes deafening.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: So...there's nothing you can tell me about Paul  Owen?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: He led what I suppose was an orderly life. He... ate a balanced diet.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: What kind of man was he? Besides... (He hesitates tries to smile)  the information you've just given.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not being cross-examined here.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Do you feel that way?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (As he writes without looking up)  Where did Paul hang out?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Hang...out?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know...hang out.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Let me think. The Newport. Harry's. Fluties. Endochine. Nell's. Comell Club. The New York Yacht Club. The regular places.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: He had a yacht?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No, he just hung out there.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: And where did he go to school? A slight pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Don't you know this?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I just wanted to know if you know.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Before Yale? If I remember correctly, Saint Paul's... Listen, I just...I just want to help.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I understand. He makes another note.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Anything else you can tell me about Owen?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: We were both seven in 1969.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (Smiles)  So was I.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Do you have any witnesses or fingerprints?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Well, there's a message on his answering machine saying h went to London.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he did, huh?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: His girlfriend doesn't think so.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: But...has anyone seen him in London?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Actually, yes.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Well, I've had a hard time getting an actual verification A Stephen Hughes says he saw him at a restaurant there, b I checked it out and what happened is, he mistook a Huber Ainsworth for Paul, so...

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Was he involved at all , do you think, in occultism or Sa worship?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I know it sounds like a lame question, but in New Jersey know this sounds like a lame question, but last month-I d know if you've heard about this, but a young stockbroker recently arrested and charged with murdering a young Chic girl and performing voodoo rituals with various body part

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Yikes! No. Paul wasn't into that. He followed a balanced  diet and-

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, and was into that whole Yale thing. A pause - the longest so far.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Have you consulted a psychic?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Had his apartment been burglarized?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No, it actually hadn't. Toiletries were missing. A  suit was gone. So was some luggage. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I mean no one's dealing with the homicide squad yet  or anything, right?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: No, not yet. As I said, we're not sure. But... basically no one has seen or heard anything.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: That's so typical, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: It's just strange.  (He stares out the window, lost in thought)  One day someone's walking around, going to work, alive,  and then...

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: People just...disappear.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: The earth just opens up and swallows people.  (He checks his Rolex)

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Eerie. Really eerie. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Standing up)  You'll have to excuse me. I have a lunch meeting  with Cliff Huxtable at Four Seasons in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Isn't the Four Seasons a little far uptown? I  mean aren't you going to be late?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Uh, no. There's one...down here.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Oh really? I didn't know that. Bateman leads him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. It's very good. KIMBALL turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Listen, if anything occurs to you, any information  at all...

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely, I'm 100% with you.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Great, and thanks for your, uh, time, Mr. Bateman. Bateman closes the door firmly on KIMBALL. He closes his  eyes and leans against the door, sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfectly lit kitchen still-life - a bottle of Evian,  a white porcelain plate on which sits a sliced kiwi, some green grapes, a few berries. OFFSCREEN, the SOUND OF SCREAMS AND A CHAINSAW can be hea from the living room. The living room: Bateman is maniacally doing abdominal  crunches as the television plays a video of Texas Chainsa Massacre. There is a pile of horror videos on his coffee next to a copy of GQ.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Bateman is sitting in his armchair, phone book in hand,  jerking off. He is squealing into the phone and breathing

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: You like that, slut? The person on the other end clearly hangs up. CLOSE-UP on his fingers dialing the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: You want to know what I'm wearing? Sixty-dollar  boxer shorts by Ralph Lauren, a hundred-and-fifty-dollar cotton T-shirt by  Commes des Garcons.  (He snorts like a pig)  My Rolex cost- Another hang-up. He dials again.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Whipering)  I'm a corporate raider. I orchestrate hostile takeovers. you think of that?  (Makes disgusting sucking noises and grunts)  Huh, bitch?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad, is that you? Bateman hangs up, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman cruises around in the limo. It pulls up alongside CHRISTIE, a pretty blonde hooker in shorts and leather ja Bateman opens his window to speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you around here.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: You just haven't been looking.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to see my apartment? Bateman flips on the light inside the limo. He's wearing tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: (looking away to some dark corner)  I'm not supposed to. Bateman is holding out a $100 bill, which Christie now  notices, then takes.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Do you want to come to my apartment or not?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to.  (She pockets the bill)  But I can make an exception.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Do you take American Express? Christie is still looking out behind her.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Do you take American Express? Christie looks at him like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I'm joking. Come on, get in. As they drive uptown, Bateman dials the cell-phone. He  reads off a credit card number.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I'd like a girl, early twenties, blonde, who does  couples. Couples. Fifty-five West Eighty-First, the  American Gardens Building. Apartment 7C. And I really  can't stress blonde enough. Blonde. He hangs up. BATEMAN I'm Paul. My name is Paul 0wen, have you'got that You are Christie. You are to respond only to Christie. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christie is in the bathtub, Bateman is pouring in white  milky bath oil.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: That's a very fine Chardonnay you're drinking. Long pause, in which Christie is luxuriating in the tub a Bateman is casually touching her breast.

dialogues.text: Burning the midnight oil, Mr. Smith? You  forgot to sign in. Bateman wheels around and shoots him. He runs toward the  revolving doors. As he swings around in the doors, he  notices a JANITOR who has witnessed the shooting. He  revolves back into the lobby and shoots the janitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out of the building and across the  street to an identical office building, the one that hous Pierce & Pierce. INT. PIERCE & PIERCE LOBBY - NIGHT  Bateman nods at the Pierce & Pierce NIGHT WATCHMAN an in. He breathes a sigh of relief as the elevator doors cl behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman stands looking out  through the floor-length windows at a panoramic night vie of the city and the river. Below him he sees a SWAT TEAM swarming over the roof of t opposite building. There are ambulances standing by, flar everywhere, distant sirens. Suddenly, THE SOUND OF A HELICOPTER draws near. Frightene he drops to the floor behind his desk. Helicopter searchlights scan the building, illuminating  Bateman's office for a few moments with a blaze of light. He is crouched in one corner, half-sobbing, talking into  the phone, as the searchlight keeps circling.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Harold, it's Bateman. Patrick Bateman. You're my  lawyer so I think you should know-I've killed a lot of  people. Some escort girls, in an apartment uptown, some  homeless people, maybe five or ten, an NYU girl I met in  Central Park. I left her in a parking lot, near Dunkin'  Donuts. I killed Bethany, my old girlfriend, with a nail  gun. and a man, some old faggot with a dog. Last week I  killed another girl with a chainsaw-I had to, she almost  got away There was someone else there, maybe a model, I  can't remember but she's dead too. And Paul Owen. I kille Paul Owen with an ax, in the face. His body is dissolving in a bathtub in Hell's Kitchen. I don't want to leave any out here...I guess I've killed 20 people, maybe 40-I have of a lot of it. Some of the girls have seen the tapes, I well, I ate some of their brains and I tried to cook a li Tonight I just, well, I had to kill a lot of people and I sure I 'm going to get away with it this time-I mean I gu I'm a pretty sick guy. So-if you get hack tomorrow, I may up at Harry's Bar, so, you know, keep your eyes open. Bateman hangs up the phone. The helicopter searchlight  circles back, briefly illuminating the room. The camera r up over Bateman huddled in the corner, staring blankly at sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KIMBALL and Bateman are sitting at a corner table.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (Very surprised)  No hash browns?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Not in the mood, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: But...everyone orders the hash browns here. I  mean- it's-have you been here before?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Deliberately nonchalant)  Yes, of course. The hash browns are delicious. I'm just.. ordering them.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (Looking at him like he's nuts)  Suit yourself, I guess. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: So, the night he disappeared? Any new thoughts on  what you did?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not really sure. I had a shower...and some  sorbet?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I think maybe you've got your dates mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: But how? Where do you place Paul that night?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: According to his date book, and this was verified by his  secretary, he had dinner with...Marcus Halberstam.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: I've questioned him.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Yes. And he denies it. Though at first he couldn't  be sure.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: But Marcus denied it?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, does Marcus have an alibi?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Yes. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: He does? You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: (smiling) I checked it out. It's clean.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh. KIMBALL Now where were you?  (He laughs)

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Laughing with him)  Where was Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: He wasn't with Paul  Owen.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: So who was he with?

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: He was at Atlantis with Craig McDermott, Frederick Dibble Harry Newman, George Butner and В–  (He pauses, Then looks up)  - you. A moment of stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Of course...We had wanted Paul Owen  to come. But he said he had plans...I guess I had dinner  with Victoria...the following night.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBALL
dialogues.text: Personally I think the guy went a little nutso. Split tow a while. Maybe he did go to London. Sightseeing. Drinking Whatever. Anyway, I'm pretty sure he'll turn up sooner or later.  (A pause)  I mean, to think that one of his friends  killed him, for no reason whatsoever would be too  ridiculous. Isn't that right, Patrick?  McDermott stops by the table.  McDERMOTT  KIMBALL! How's the investigation?  Talking to Bateman? Don't believe a word he says.  (Laughs uproariously slapping him on the back)  Bateman, what's wrong with ,you?  Bateman looks at him in silence,  panicking.  McDERMOTT  You can't eat at Smith and Wollensky  without ordering the hash browns. Jesus, Bateman, you're raving maniac. Been at Pierce & Pierce too long.  (He wanders off muttering)  No fucking hash browns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman walks into the lobby of Paul Owen's building. He  has a surgical mask in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: Of course. Mrs. Wolfe is up there right now.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wolfe?

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: The real estate agent? You do have an appointment, don't you? Bateman steps out of the elevator and walks cautiously do the hallway. Owen's door is open. The apartment is freshl painted and has been immaculately redecorated in English  country-house style: overstuffed sofas, lots of chintz. T are flowers everywhere, and a YOUNG YUPPIE COUPLE stands  admiring the place talkingto the realtor, MRS. WOLFE. Bat wanders down the hallway, looking for familiar signs. He at the closet where we last saw two dead girls hanging. H opens the door and the light switches on, but it is empty Wolfe approaches, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: Are you my two o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No. Mrs. Wolfe eyes him strangely, then looks down at the  surgical mash clutched in his hand. Her expression change

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for...Paul Owen's...place. She stares at him impassively.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Doesn't he live here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: No, he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: You saw the ad in the Times?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No. Yes. I mean yes, I did. In the Times. But... doesn't Paul Owen still live here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: There was no ad in the Times. Bateman is shaking as they continue to stare at each othe

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: I think you should go now.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: But I think...I want to know what happened  here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: Don't make any trouble. Please. I suggest you go. Bateman backs away slowly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
dialogues.text: Don't come back.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I won't...don't worry. Mrs. Wolfe glares at him as he walks down the hall,  rattled, and gets into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman enters the revolving  door of an office building, panicking and breathing  heavily. He is sweating, his hair is wild, and he looks  deranged. He goes around the revolving door twice and com out onto the street again, where he bumps smack into a GU just like him.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, Kinsley. Bateman looks up at him wild-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: See you at Fluties, okay? The guy walks away, utterly unfazed. Bateman wanders down the street, banging his briefcase against walls, garbage  cans, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman searches his pockets  for pills. He finds three different pills and swallows  them. He's sweating, and takes his jacket off to wipe his face, dialing a number.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Patrick Bateman's office.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Jean? Hello? Jean?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Patrick? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Hello? Jean, I need help!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Jean-I'm not-

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Craig McDermott called. He wants to meet you and  David Van Patten and Tim Price at Harry's for drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh God, what did you say, you dumb bitch?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Patrick? I can't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: What are I doing?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you? Patrick, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm gonna make it, Jean. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: ...to the office this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Screaming)  Just...say...no!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What is it, Patrick? Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Stop sounding so Fucking sad! Jesus! He hangs up. He throws the Walkman which is around his ne into a nearby trash can, and wipes his face with his  jacket.

He spots his friends in a corner, sits do still breathing heavily. Price is on his cell-phone, trying to get reservations. McDERMOTT  Bateman, you're looking a little wild-eyed rough  day at the office? They all laugh. McDERMOTT  Hey, look-Price is back. And he's drinking  Perrier. He s a changed man. Except...he still can't  get a reservation to save his life. Bateman sits down silently. McDERMOTT  Why don't you try I 50 Wooster? Just fucking call them.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (On automatic)  I'm not going anywhere unless we  have a reservation. VAN PATTEN Le Cirque, Flamingo East, Oyster Bar, come on, faggots-just get a res.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Keep your shirt on. Maybe lose the suspenders. Bateman spots HAROLD CARNES at the bar, tenses.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (He downs his drink)  Excuse me, gentlemen. Right back. He approaches Carnes cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Face it-the Japanese will own most of this country by the end of the '90s. Bateman approaches, trying to act casual.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Carnes, they will not. Carnes is surprised, turns around, looks vaguely confused

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: So, Harold, did you get my message? Carnes lights a cigarette, stalling. Then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Jesus, Davis. Yes. That was hilarious. That was you,  wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Waving smoke out of his face)  Yes, naturally.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Bateman killing Owen and the escort girls? Oh that s  fabulous. That's rich... Pause

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: It was a pretty long message, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: What exactly do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: The message you left. Carnes is distracted, waving at people.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: By the way Davis, how is Cynthia? You're still  seeing her, right?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: But wait, Harold, what do you mean? Carnes isn't really listening.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Nothing. Good to see you. Is that Edward Tower He turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Carnes? Wait.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: (Sighing)  Davis. I'm not one to bad-mouth anyone, your joke was amu But come on, man, you had one fatal flaw: Bateman's such such a boring, spineless lightweight, that I couldn't ful appreciate it. I wasn't fooled for a second. Now, if you' Price, or McDermott...Otherwise, it was amusing. Now, let have lunch or dinner or something. Hilarious, Davis. A ki

dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Bateman is what?

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Oh Christ. He can barely pick up an escort girl, let  alone...what was it you said he did to her? Carnes looks around the club, raises his glass to a passi couple. He laughs politely.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Now, if you'll excuse me, I really must...

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: (Desperate, shouting)  Wait. Stop. You don't seem to understand. You're not real comprehending any of this. I killed him. I did it, Carnes I'm Patrick Bateman. I chopped Owen's fucking head off.  I tortured dozens of girls. The whole message I left on y machine was true.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I really must he going.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No! Listen, don't you know who I am? I'm not Davis, I'm  Patrick Bateman! I talk to you on the phone all the time! Don't you recognize me? You're my lawyer. Carnes stares at him in confusion and annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Now, Carnes, listen to me. Listen very, very carefully. I Paul Owen and I liked it. I can't make myself any clearer

dialogues.text: But that's simply not possible. And I don't find  this funny anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: It never was supposed to he! Why isn't it possible?

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: (Eyeing Bateman worriedly) It's just not.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: Why not, you stupid bastard? Carnes stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Because I had dinner with Paul Owen twice in  London...just ten days ago.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: No, you...didn't?

dialogues.speaker: CARNES
dialogues.text: Now, if you'll excuse me. Bateman returns back to his friends' table, in a daze. They are all looking at the television, where Ronald  Reagan is giving a speech about Iran Contra. They are  halfheartedly arguing about whether or not he's  lying.

dialogues.text: How can he lie like that? How can he pull that shit?

dialogues.text: What shit? Now where do we have reservations at?  I mean I'm not really hungry, but I would like to have  reservations somewhere.

dialogues.text: (To Bateman)  I don't believe it. He looks so...normal. He seems so... out of it. So...undangerous. McDERMOTT  He is totally harmless you geek. Was totally harmless. Just like you are totally harmless. But he did do all tha shit and you have failed lo get us into I 50, so, you kno what can I say?

dialogues.text: I just don't see how someone, anyone, can appear that  way and yet be involved in such total shit. How can you b fucking, I don't know, cool about it?

dialogues.speaker: VAN PATTEN
dialogues.text: Some guys are just born cool, I guess. Bateman laughs at this. Price shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: And Bateman, what are YOU SO fucking zany about?

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: I'm just a happy camper. Rockin' and a-rollin'.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PATTEN
dialogues.text: (To Price) Rehab's done wonders for you, pal.  Working for UNICEF now? McDERMOTT  Do you want another Perrier Timothy? Some seltzer water?

dialogues.text: Oh brother look-he presents himself as a harmless  Old codger. But inside... Pause.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE

dialogues.text: There are no more barriers to cross. All I have in common the uncontrollable and the insane, the vicious and the ev all the mayhem I have caused and my utter indifference to it, I have now surpassed...

dialogues.text: My pain is constant and sharp and I do not hope for a bet world for anyone. I fact I want my pain to be inflicted o others. I want no escape.
